steps.title: It should resemble a bowling pin that has been knocked down.
steps.content: It should resemble a bowling pin that has been knocked down. Give the tail a little bit of an angle around the top and bottom.

steps.title: Draw a circular eye for your fish.
steps.content: Draw a circular eye for your fish. This will help you get a better idea of the overall look of your fish.

steps.title: There should be one fin on top, and one fin on the body.
steps.content: There should be one fin on top, and one fin on the body. If it helps, add a few lines to show where the gill would be (you can’t really see it in a finished picture), and where the tail begins.

steps.title: There are a few different options here, so get creative.
steps.content: There are a few different options here, so get creative. Decide what type of pattern your clownfish will have, and draw it in.

steps.title: This should be a very minor addition, since clownfish have tiny mouths.
steps.content: This should be a very minor addition, since clownfish have tiny mouths. It is close to the “chin” on the fish’s head.

steps.title: Refine the fins and pattern to really make it pop.
steps.content: Refine the fins and pattern to really make it pop. Use different wrist movements and strokes to give your drawing some variation.

steps.title: Orange and white are the iconic colors, but feel free to mix it up.
steps.content: Orange and white are the iconic colors, but feel free to mix it up. While the orange and white pattern is probably the first thing you think of, clownfish come in a wide variety of colors, from bright yellow to almost black.

steps.title: For a more realistic fish, add some dark and light highlights.
steps.content: For a more realistic fish, add some dark and light highlights. This will give your fish a more dynamic look.

steps.title: For a more complete illustration, add some background details.
steps.content: For a more complete illustration, add some background details. Bubbles, aquatic plants, and even other fish can all work well.
